text: Hey all -- we're looking to hire a freelancer to help us re-write our website (<http://uptickapp.com|uptickapp.com>). Looking for someone who is an excellent storyteller and has experience writing sales focused copy for a saas product. Interested? Click the :hand: below and I'll reach out to you with more info. Have someone to recommend that I should reach out to? Shoot me a message with their info. Thanks in advance!

text: Hi! Has anyone used a sprint structure for your marketing team? If so, do you have any resources you suggest?

elements.text: Hi! Has anyone used a sprint structure for your marketing team? If so, do you have any resources you suggest?

text: There is (surprisingly?) a solid introductory-level LinkedIn Learning class on this very topic. It's titled something like "Agile Marketing." If you don't have a premium LinkedIn account, your local public library system probably has a membership and all you need is your library card to access the class for free. My old project manager had the entire department watch some of the class when we switched to an Agile framework. It didn't suck. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Thank you so much, <@UUKNTTCCR>! :pray::skin-tone-2: I am going to check this out tonight (I just upgraded). Do you like the sprint format?

elements.text: I am going to check this out tonight (I just upgraded). Do you like the sprint format?

text: I do like the sprint format. My current agency has a "buffet" style relationship with the agile framework, so I don't use sprints as much as I did in my previous gig. Currently, we don't use all Agile pieces, but have daily standups and retrospectives and use sprints for internal projects (once a week, four-hour blocks). Only two of our clients use sprints, though, so we rarely use that terminology when talking about client projects. I think at some point we tried to use sprints with all of our client projects (before I worked here), but it sounds like trying to get every project on a set structure just became impossible. Heck, we can't even get all of our clients to buy into our project management software, so we find ourselves manually submitting tickets on their behalf. Long way to say that I like it but we're not fully immersed in it—we pick and choose.

text:
Technically not "marketing marketing" but the product content strategists I work with at eBay use a sprint structure for requests.

They actually use JIRA for all inbound content requests alongside Engineering. It works very well and when I help with UI/UX content, I'll often be looped in on those tickets.

Our localization teams also use JIRA and I believe our Customer Success content team also follows that model.

For me directly, I work in GTM (go to market) and am putting out fires every few days and fielding inbound requests from 14 markets globally.

I've looked into using JIRA for myself, but it was way too much for me. I ended up using Google Sheets to create a lite tracker of projects and tasks.
